reviewText:
I highly recommend this game. Not because I'm a big fan, but During my time playing it, it really hits home.

First of all, the game is very different from the previous two. There is only one animatronic. Now you may think that is easy.  Come on, like only one? While this is technically true, there are the other animatronics (in the form of hallucinations), like I've seen Foxy, Chica, BB, etc., that act as distractions by jumpscaring you, so that mister new guy can say hello.

Second of all, the new defense system isn't very obvious, which I like. There are two main defenses (at least I think), which is the audio system (consisting of BB's HI's HELLO's and HAHAHA's) , and the ventellation grates. The audio is used to lure the new guy away from you and the ventellation is used to block certain vents so he can't crawl through them, one of these leading straight to your office, which can allow for some new strategies on how to survive the nights.

Third of all, is the atmosphere. I never feel safe when I play this game, dreading that something will be jumping in my face. In the game, there is a big wide window in front of you, in which is implemented greatly, as sometimes you can see Freddy limping to your door, to the new guy staring at you, then dashing away, even to him peaking at you while trying to stay hidden. It reflects the game's mood, which is what I like the most.

In general, I believe that this game is the creepiest game in the trilogy, offering new scares, more stress for you to get over, and new secrets to discover.

P.S: Things that I look forward to;
- Golden Freddy (if he exists)
- The Custom Night (1/20 or more...)


Update:
I've done some research, and I think I can confirm that there is no custom night which makes sense (you only got SpringTrap really) but thats fine as there are a lot of secrets that makes me keep searching for them. Also I don't know if Golden Freddy exists or not.

Anyway, thanks for the comments!


Another Update:
Golden Freddy does exist in this game. Just search it up on youtube!

reviewText:
4 quick tips on how to get ready for Freddy 3:

1. Distract the animatronic by using your audio equipment.
2. Make sure to watch ventilation system. However do not worry about checking it like you would the regular cameras. You will hear when an animatronic is up above you and that is when you should check.
3. Reboot your audio, cameras, and ventilation system as soon as it is malfunctioning.
4. Look out for animatronic hallucinations. If you stare at any, then get ready for a jump scare. What’s worse is if you see Marionette, it will prevent you from doing anything until it decides to go away. And that creepy face...

reviewText:
Five Nights at Freddy's 3...oh boy. This series has been notorious for its fast sequels (or prequels) and recently the rumoured last installment of the series has finally come out.

So, this review will answer one question: Is Five Nights at Freddy's 3 actually scary or just a jumpscare fest?
Long Description on the Game (Look below for a summary):Five Nights at Freddy's 3 has a completely different gameplay from its predecessors. The only gameplay mechanics that remain are winning at 6 AM and the office and cameras. Other than that, nearly everything has been removed and/or changed. In Five Nights at Freddy's 3, there is a control panel where you can monitor the status of systems like Ventilation and such. These systems will randomly go offline and cause your death as most of them are required to stop the animatronic from reaching you. You can now play a sound in the cameras to lure the animatronic away from you, although the system errors might mess you up and cause your death. Cameras are now more staticy and the animatronic isn't as visible anymore in the cameras. This causes the user to rapidly search for where the animatronic is and strikes fear into their hearts. Five Nights at Freddy's 3 is no longer a reflex game unlike the second installment. It, however, still keeps your heart pumping.
Losing causes a jumpscare however this is not why it is scary. Most of the time when I was playing, I was panicking and getting scared due to losing track of where the animatronic went. Not only that, this animatronic can peek through the windows of the Office. The animatronic can walk past the window and run past you. There are, also, hallucinations of the animatronics from the previous games and they cause a jumpscare and system failure. Some people might call this a cheap way to scare the user but it really isn't scary anymore after the first few times. The reason they are there is to cause system failures in a different way (other than them randomly going out). To me, this was executed in the best way possible.

Summary:
Pros:- New scary and dark atmosphere due to the pizzeria being abandoned.
- MUCH better jumpscares (These are NOT the reasons why the game is scary)
- Hallucinations of characters from the previous games
- Story is finally nearly pieced together
- Brand new gameplay mechanics
- Completely different from the earlier games
- No longer a reflex game (unlike the second installment)
- Animatronic isn't easily visible in cams (causing player to panic)
- Multiple cam sections (Normal and Vents)
- A brand new extras menu
- Cheats
- A window where animatronic(s) can walk past and stare
- Bigger Office
- Freddy's Nose

Cons:- Animatronic can sometimes teleport" from one end of the cam to the office
- Hallucinations might bug sometimes
- You will not understand the story if you have not played the previous games
- Gameplay mechanics can be confusing at first

Overall:Therefore
recommended: Five Nights at Freddy's 3 is not a jumpscare fest and is by far the best horror game in the series. It is also a good indie horror game that is actually pretty cheap.\nYou should pick it up if you are looking for a good horror game or are a fan of the series."

reviewText: In this game, you must avoid the new animatronic(Idk what the heck to even describe it as tbh), who is VERY jealous of your role as security guard! Always one to scare an employee away, you must remain at your post until 6 AM or he'll take over! Worry not, for you're not alone! The old animatronics are there to help you out! Balloon Boy will distract the new animatronic's attention by calling out friendly greetings, while the others tamper with the vents to confuse him with the flashing lights! Even Freddy is on your side! On night 3, he came by the window and sensing I was in danger, gave me a big ol' bear hug while using his body to shield me! A game about true friendship, rivalry, and dedication to your job! 10/10, great for the whole family!

reviewText:
After a lot of hard work, I finally 3-stared the game, and holy crap does it feel good! I kid you not, I actually shed a tear of relief when the clock ticked over to 6:00 AM on Night 6.

To do the game justice, I'm rewriting my recommendation now that I've completed everything that the game seems to offer, but I'll include the original recommendation in a comment in the description if you're interested in reading some of my first impressions on it.

So, would I recommend it? Hell yes. It was incredibly satisfying working to get a grasp of all the mechanics, but the game still has a huge element of unpredictability, so even when you think you'll be able to pull of the hardest challenges it offers, you may still end up short. It is this feeling of utter helplessness at times that makes it such a good horror experience, and I think FNaF 3 manages to capture this to an even greater extent than either of the first two games.

If you're new to the Freddy experience, this should be a pretty interesting and wild ride for you, but I would honestly recommend that you start from the beginning of the series or at least watch a playthrough on YouTube, as you will miss out on the best parts of the overarching story as well as the subtle changes in game mechanics that are present throughout.

For the long time fans of the series, you get a lot of answers and even some closure to a lot of big plot points in here, and I won't spoil anything in writing here, but I have posted some spoilery screenshots if you have the desire to view them.

Ultimately, this feels like a great possible conclusion for the FNaF franchise, which it might very well be, but rumors are plentiful everywhere you look, so we'll just have to see what Scott does. Either way, if this is the end or not, I have thoroughly enjoyed the experience, and I honestly believe the FNaF-series is a milestone in the horror genre that won't be easily forgotten.

If you're still sticking around, thanks a lot for reading, and take care!

-Kelso

Hopefully some people will be able to read this before the rabid FNAF fans downvote this into oblivion.

Pros
-Story ends in a satisfying conclusion...

Cons
-...and is immediately undone by a crappy sequel hook
-No strategy. The game consists of pinballing the enemy between two rooms for 4 nights.
- Only 4 main nights of actual gameplay. The first night is a danger-free tutorial.
-No atmosphere. There are no random events on cameras, only a few tired jumpscares, and the previous animatronics are waved in our face as they go ooglyboogly" in a pathetic attempt to try and get points for nostalgia as cheap scares.
-The game can be completed in under an hour.

This is a rushed and downright poor game. This would be unacceptable as a standalone game

reviewText:
Well...Five Nights at Freddy's 3. After five months of waiting, the third, and most likely the final, installment to the highly acclaimed Five Nights at Freddy's saga has been released. I was well into the hype as soon as the first teasers popped up on Scottgames.com, and was one of the very few people that waited patiently for the release. Yeah, I will be honest, the community kinda sucks when it comes to being patient. Granted, there are people who respect Scott's wishes to take his time to make a quality game, but there are still people that are not afraid to badger the poor guy. But, I digress.

Anyway, FNaF 3 is likely the most hyped up game in the entire series. Not only did it take more time than FNaF 2 in terms of development, but it also promised a lot of major changes to the gameplay as a whole, as well as the story. Speaking of which, FNaF 3 takes place 30 years after the events of Five nights 1 and 2 (which automatically clears up timeline discussions, thank god), and is instead in the halls of a horror attraction. Scott Cawthon reprises his role as the phone guy, who is now a more modernised individual, and also a different individual altogether. Don't worry, fans of original Phone Guy, for he also makes a return. How? Through pre-recorded audio tapes that are meant to teach pizzeria employees how to use the spring loaded hybrid suits, which are designed to be human suits and animatronic suits. This ties in to our new enemy, Spring Trap, who lurks the halls on night two and onward (night 1 is a freebie level that talks you through using the different mechanics, which I'll go through in a moment).

Now, the fact that there is only one main enemy will make the game sound really easy. However, Scott has once again pulled some clever tricks out of his sleeves. For starters, you can now access two parts of the building: the main halls and the vents. In the main halls, you can play audio in any room to lure Spring Trap away from you or a vent. In the vents, you can seal any ONE vents to prevent Spring from going through it. That's right, only one, so it's best to be wise when choosing a vent to seal. Of course, with all of this stuff, it would make the game even easier, if not for the reboot system. The vents, audio, and even the CAMERAS can and will break down at certain times and under certain conditions. In order to fix these issues, you have to reboot that system through a menu on the left part of the screen. When rebooting any and all systems, you cannot access cameras or exit from the reboot menu, leaving you open for attack, so be sure to wait until the right moment.

Okay, okay, now this may seem like it would still be easy, but I'm only just getting to the good part. Our favorite animatronics make a surprising return, but not as animatronics that kill you. Instead, they will randomly come to your office as hallucinations, or phantoms as they're called in-game, and jump at you, causing you to be temporarily blinded and causing your vents to break, meaning Spring has an easy window to come and get you.

The animatronics are not the only returning element. The death minigames from FNaF 2 also come back, but not after you die. Rather, they appear in between levels, telling you the story of the birth of Spring Trap. I'm not going to spoil it for you, but trust me when I say that the twist at the end is more than unsettling, combined with the ending overall.

Upon completing the main campaign, you get three different replay incentives. For one, there are two different endings to the game itself. The bad ending is what you get if you play the game normally, but the good ending is quite a tricky devil to unlock. You'd likely be better off searching it on Youtube once you beat the game, since the ending cutscene doesn't change either way. Secondly, you get Nightmare mode, which is, rather disappointingly, the hardest mode in the game. It's not disappointing in a sense that it's easy or anything, but it means that there is no seventh custom night, unless there is one in the extras area, which is the third item you unlock after beating night 5. Extras mode lets you see the sprites and jumpscares of the animatronics, as well as hidden minigames and cheats. I'm not yet certain if one of the cheats includes the custom night mode, as I haven't unlocked that portion yet (cheats and jumpscares are unlocked via beating Nightmare Mode), but we should find out very soon.

Overall, this game is easily one of my favorites from this year, as well as my favorite in the series. It may not be as content filled as the first or second game, or even as scary (though the phantoms did get me a few times), I still find FNaF 3 to be a worthy follow up, as well as a great way to end a great franchise (and yes, I KNOW that it's foolish of me to jump the gun on that statement, but honestly, there's enough red flags in this game to show that this is at least the last game for a WHILE). I'll be honest, while I will happily follow whatever Scott makes in the future, I hope he at least takes a break from thsi franchise. Great games or not, three games consecutively in just one year could take a lot out of even the most skilled developers. I wouldn't know, since I've never made a game (though I am considering making a FNaF fangame just to get familiar with Clickteam Fusion, which is the engine used in this series), but I can imagine that it's hard work. Either way, to Scott if he somehow finds and reads this, do whatever you want to do. From what I've seen, you have a passion for making games, and you're certainly a person I've been looking up to. Whether you decide to make Five Nights at Freddy's 4: Electric Boogaloo, or even make another ip in the horror genre, I look forward to whatever you make.

Also, on a final note, try the mobile version if you're interested. After playing the demo for a little bit, I find that version to be a bit easier to get into than the PC version, at the cost of not having as many features of course.

reviewText:
Fun little game. Not really a horror, but sometimes it manages to surprise or confuse you.
Atmosphere is very good, and is actually the reason why I bought it. The sounds, gloomy lightning, battered faces of the monsters. Feels very interesting.

There's one major drawback to this game: after a while, you'll find out the principles and you'll just mechanically mouseclick. It gets boring too fast.

reviewText:
Five nights at freddy's 3 is an amazing game with jumpscares, a scary atmospere and great gamplay.
Even though there is only one animatronice the game's still fun because its done diffrently (e.g. there's nothing to keep you safe once its in the office like the mask and there are also no doors to lock it out with.) To survive each night you must use balloon boys recorded voice to trick Springtrap (the animatronice) into thinking there's a child in the room you use the audio in. You must also check the airvents when you hear a thumping noise so you can seal the vent that Springtraps in. This makes the game sound easy but when you use the audio it takes a little while before you can use it again. There is also a thing called the maintanence panel which youu have to use if you use the audio to many times(so the audio system fails), the camera system fails or the ventalation fails. The maintanance panel is almost the equivelent of the music box from the second game. It takes a long time to reboot each system giving Springtrap a chance to come into your office. If the audio fails and you don't reboot it there will be nothing to lead Springtrap away from your office, if the camera systems fail and you don't reboot them all you'll see is static when you look at the cameras so you won't know where springtrap is and if the ventalation fails your charecter's vision will keep flashing black if you don't reboot the system. Although technecly there's only one animatronice there are also hallucinations of some of the animatronices from the previous games, the hallucinations can't actually kill you but they can jump scare and disable the ventalation or audio.

I reckon Scott Cawthon has done a great job and i highly recommend the game!

reviewText:
I played a bit but mostly watched youtube players play the game. I did find the game fun, but it seems much shorter than he other two games. Since I can't give a full review I will give a summary of the first few nights I played:

Night 1: Get the intro done and enjoy the atmosphere of the place.
Figure out the sound system and check reboot times.

Night 2: Get ready for the real thing.
Find spring trap and start to play sounds.
Cat decides to sit on my lap while I play.
Cat watches the computer mouse on the screen and bats at it.
Flipping through the cameras making noise for Springy.
Cat stares at my mouse intently.
See BB on camera.
BB Jumpscare.
Cat flips out, Claws dig into my leg.
Can jumps off my lap in a meowing tizzy.
Cat is caught in my headphone cables.
Headphones rip off, cat scurries onto the floor, wriggling in the cables.
The monitor the cables are strung through drags to the edge.
Grab monitor trying to save it.
Cat gets free and runs off.
Cat judges me while I try to fix my setup.
Finally get headphones back on and setup fixed.
Spring trap jumps into my room.
Can hear cat laugh at my misfortune in the other room.

Day 3:
Cat back on lap.
Decided it was best to not play the game again for a while...

reviewText:
30 years after the terror that happened at Freddy Fazbear's Pizza restaurant causing the original owner to shut it down, new owners open Fazbear's Fright: The Horror Attraction with the intention of reviving the legendary terror as a thrilling experience for customers. The new owners manage to find and salvage one of the original animatronics to use as a prop for their new business... and now the real terror begins again... it's no horror attraction. It's real.

Again, you work as security in an open office without a door to keep you safe as you look through the security cams and maintain the audio, camera and ventilation systems.

All alone and already freaked out from the environment, your mind begins playing tricks on you. This time there no flashlights, no camera lights and no masks to disguise yourself. You will find a lot of jump scare hallucinations seeing animatronics from the previous Five Night's at Freddy's and experience panic attacks with shortness of breath, causing you to have blacks outs. Those jump scare hallucinations will scare you. xD

One of the changes in FNAF3 aside from the hallucinations is the ventilation system which now has a sealing switch to prevent the animatronic from getting through them. Bad luck for you though, that sealing switch only affects one vent at a time. :/

Get this game at your own risk. If you can't handle jump scares... suck it up and get it anyway. LOL. xD

I uploaded some gameplay for you to check out:
http://youtu.be/rLttX1Oz2Rk
voteText: 117 of 199 people (59%) found this review helpful 31 people found this review funny

reviewText: This installment of FNAF forces you into a more panic and intense state, The one and only enemy hides in the already hard to see cameras, causing you to have to stop and search for him (which creates a very fun, intense high) Do this while avoiding contact with the hallucinations, each of them having their own one way to subdue you. The story isn't much to grip you through the nights but the core gameplay will make you feel rewarded after each level is finished.\n\nIn the end this game gives you a fun, energetic, panicky high, all the feelings you would get in a real horror situation from the saftey of your room. Exactly what a horror games needs.

reviewText:
Do you want a review of why FNAF 3 is bad without a crap load of hate remarks? You've come to the right place. (WARNING SPOILERS)

Simply put, FNAF 3 fails where FNAF's 1 and 2 have prevailed
HOWEVER, it also prevailed where 1 and 2 didn't, which will be explained towards the bottom.
FNAF 3 has 3 major downfalls. Gameplay, Scare Factor, and overall functionality.

GAMEPLAY: FNAF 3's gameplay revolves around the 1 new animatronic, being the only animatronic (aside for of course the phantom ones. Their purpose is to make you reset the ventilation and also to scare you). The problem with him is that he is never explained. Now I LOVE games where you have to figure out what you're doing, as I grew up with NES classics. HOWEVER, I have obtained 3 stars and I still do not know how he works. I have, of course, found out how certain things work, enough to (obviously) beat the game. But there is no explanation. None. You are left to scramble about, trying to survive night 3 since nights 1 and 2 its nearly impossible to die, while also trying to figure out how the thing you're trying to prevent from entering your room works. The system monitor only prevents you further from understanding how Spring Trap works. Instead of having the first night have no animatronic however still having the system menu, they should have made it the opposite, to allow time for the player to understand the ways of Spring Trap. Overall, the gameplay is too strange to go without explanation, thus confusing the player and making the game as luck based as FNAF 1 on 4/20 mode. Which, if you look at the forums, you'll find people who beat it in less than 3 hours like me (which, on its own, is ENTIRELY dissapointing) and people who cant get past night 3 even while using strategies that've worked for everyone else. It's a mess, and it needs either revision or explanation.

SCARE FACTOR: You can watch any Youtuber and they'll be scared ****less. But you must understand that's their job. This game is not scary. AT ALL. In fact, the scariest thing in the game can't even kill you, as it is the phantom animatronics' jumpscare sprites. You can beat this game and look for yourself, both death animations look like Spring Trap is just like ayyyy how goes it blargh". Remember in FNAF 1 when Freddy just goes and freaking TACKLES you in his death animation? Or in FNAF 2
date: when Old Bonnie takes off your mask and reaches for your neck! But in FNAF 3
recommended: the one thing that can kill you has an animation less scary than FNAF 1's Foxy
hoursPlayed: because at least that was accompanied with a horrific sound. A scary death noise or animation are both absent in FNAF 3. It is unfortunate how little this game has in the line of attempts at scaring the player. However
voteText:
it is something that should not be overlooked.

FUNCTIONALITY:
Oh Scott.
Oh dear dear Scott.
You finished this one too early my friend.
Far too early.
The game has one bug. One. Bug.
It randomly closes upon starting a night.
I could end the review now

reviewText:
FNaF 3 is actually my favorite one out of the 4 main games. It's a lot easier then the other ones, and really not that scary, but at this point that's not what it's about. Since FNaF2 that's not what the series is about. Obviously people like Markiplier, and ugh, PewDiePie, are infamous players of the series, and have quite a loud mouth about it too.

But believe me, it's more than gameplay, it's a story. Each game was meant to be another part of the story. Now for my speculation, 3 is the end of the timeline.

1. Kids souls are set free
2. The still mysterious purple guy" meets his doom

tl;dr FNaF isn't so much about the gameplay as much as it was in the first 2
date: but more the story in between it all"

reviewText:
This game is really fun! Even though its really challenging.

The main goal of the game is to get the animatonic (Springtrap) away from you as long as the night. There are many things that can stop you. Random errors can occur and phantoms can stop you. When you have a error, you go to the control panel and boot them up.  It takes about 5-8 seconds. If you choose reboot all, then it takes 10-12 seconds. There are also phantoms that trigger errors, and a phantom  (The Puppet), can get in your face for about 12 seconds. You use the play audio to lure springtrap away. But, if the audio error goes off, then you cant use it. Video errors can make you not see, and ventilation errors can make you hallucnate. There are also vents that he can go through, but you can seal them in.

Anyway, I rate this 100/100

reviewText:
The game is AWESOME! Highly recommend it for people who love lore. Here are my Pros and Cons.

Pros:
- The whole FNAF 1 gang is back to 'Scare your Socks off' in the new Fazbear's Fright: Horror Attraction!
- Enjoy Phantom Freddy's amazing Conga skills :D
- After 30 years, Freddy's rusty ol' nose Still Honks...
- Witness the lore of how Springtrap became Springtrap.
- Several new jumpscares of Phantoms and some from Springtrap!
Cons:
- After three games, STILL NO ANIMATION ON THE CAMERAS!
- Only two of the toy animatronics join the others...
- Wheres Bonnie? And why is Springtrap a Golden rab- ooohh.....
- Still doesn't answer all the questions of lore... (Coming Soon! Fredbear's Diner: The Invasion of the Spring-droids)

Though there are quite a few things that could have been added to make this game better, I still Highly recommend it!

reviewText:
Five nights at Freddy's 3 is one of the scariest game i played in a while.
it's even scarier than the first two five nights at Freddy's game to be honest.
i played the first and the second one and i like it so much. But this one is even better
The jumpscares in this one are scary and unpredictable.
The atmosphere and the sound in this game is creepy.
Five nights at Freddy's 3 is easier than Five nights at Freddy's 2 and i like it.
and more reason why i love this game is because they bring the old system back. which is you can watch all of the camera. Because in the second one you can only watch one camera to wind up the music box.

The only way to defense yourself in this game is to keep an eye on springtrap and don't let him get to your room.
because there are no doors and mask.

I already beat night 1 - 5. so here is a tip that i use:
1. on the begining of the night, go find where the heck Springtrap is in the camera
2. if you find him, keep an eye on him until he left
3. play the Audio to distract him and he'll be back to the room
4. keep doing that and reboot the system if error
5. you must listen to the Springtrap movement
6. if springtrap is already in the ventilation, seal it as quickly as possible
7. Springtrap will be back into one of the room
8. keep doing that until 6 AM

oh yeah, and the last thing you need to play this game is LUCK......
and i forgot to mention that the scariest thing in this game is the STORY and the MINI GAMES.
the mini games is disturbing as hell. creepy.
This game is kinda addictive.

I HIGHLY RECOMMENDED THIS GAME TO ALL OF YOU PEOPLE WHO LOVE HORROR GAMES AND FOR THOSE WHO HAD PLAYED FNAF 1 AND FNAF 2.

10/10 for me

reviewText:
Alright, I am a fan of the FNaF series, I voted for the game to be greenlit when it was still obscure, before it even touched youtube, I voted on the second one, high hopes for a sequel. I played and enjoyed both games, they worked well with eachother, sometimes annoying but decent controls, I've even found myself liking many of the characters and such almost as if I'd been in that pizzaria in person and felt nostalgia.... But this game.... Oh this game.. Scott rushed it, its blatantly obvious he rushed it. He said he was taking his time, still working on the game, Beta test results, and then releases the full game RIGHT after the demo... Big, bloody, mistake. I love FNaF, I truly do, but this game is a collosal blemish on the FNaF series, and here is why.

Repair mechanic: On paper, and even in gameplay a bit, this seems like a really good idea, functional to an extent, and made sort of a lick of sense. Then you have audio go out after one use, cameras going on and off more than a child messing with light switches, and then ventilation more faulty than lower class condos, and THAT is saying something. A repair mechanic is interesting and can add challenge, but not when my sister's cat is more cooperative than this darn device. A CAT.

The Phantoms: BB, Chica, Marionette, Freddy, Mangle, and Foxy, all of them with decently made jumpscares, none of them can hurt you. Yeah, a bit of a red light having jumpscares as threatening as a fridge magnet, but it evens itself out, or rather tries to, by disabling some of your equipment in the process. Primarily it seems they mess with ventilation above all, and sometimes touch the other two for extra annoyance. annoyance? what could be annoying?" I assume you're not asking yourself

reviewText:
Definitely an improvment on the series.
The first game was just scary, and that was at the end of the night, whether you died or not.
The second game was not scary at all, but it was stressful and had a genius backstory, which I love.

THIS ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of a game here is a mixture of both, and the slow cursor movement doesn't help my short anxiety whenever i move to see if Springtrap is coming to kill me.

(not being critical, I'm just trying to explain what this game does to you)

So yeah, take the spooks of the first game and add in the stress of the second game and triple the effects, you get this game.

reviewText:
I love Five Nights at Freddy's a little too much, but this last iteration of the series felt... lacking somehow.
(not to mention a little glitchy)
Fnaf 3 is pretty freaking spooky to be honest. Springtrap is foreboding, BB is horrifying, and watching Freddy stumble across your window, almost taunting you-
It all looks very good. Watching the animatronics move is quite refreshing, and it makes you feel just that much more helpless than before.

The Pros?
- Moving animatronics

-The disgusting run down building and animatronics are very atmospheric

-A plethora of hidden minigames

-The minigames themselves are challanging to figure out, but not impossible. The new style is great, and the pixel art is very creepy, definately an upgrade from fnaf2.

-provides some much needed plot information

-Truly frightening jumpscares

-Phone guy audio is very interesting

-Leading Springtrap around with sound is a cool new concept

-The ability to lock down vents is very helpful

-Leaving you alone the first night is an amazing way to let you start to figure out the controls and new mechanics
-its fnaf 3

HOWEVER, for everything this game does right, it seems to fall short on several other accounts.
Cons:

-The minigames might be a little TOO hard to find sometimes

-Once the puppet gets you its pretty much game over since he lingers far too long, and avoiding him is near      impossible.

-There seems to be a glitch where you can see springtrap in two different locations at the same time
(very disorienting- seriously needs to be fixed)

-Once springtrap gets up to your window or door, theres nothing you can really do to get rid of him, usually leading to      a very punishing and unfair defeat ( unfortunately this seems to be the trend with most of these cons :\)

-Springtrap likes to teleport to your office from cam 2 or 3 without using vents (really upsetting since once he gets to you he cant be led away)

-Sometimes Springtrap likes to ignore your audio cues. Not sure if its a glitch, intentional, or if im doing something wrong, but its seriously upsetting.

-no tutorial or instructions to help you actually figure out the mechanics (not everyone enjoys trial and error)

-Springtrap's jumpscare is nonexistant (he looks more like he wants to hug you)

-The jumpscares dont seem to have any pattern or method of avoidance (namely foxy, freddy, and by the time you SEE puppet its too late to switch cams. also, I can only ever get away from chica SOMETIMES)

-Springtrap travels through the vents WAAAY too quickly. Once one of your systems goes offline, he usually decides to get in a vent and travel into or up to your office before you can even finish rebooting.

-This one may be a nitpick, but I prefer that failure not be left up to random chance.
It would be nice if ALL of the jumpscares had a warning of some sort, or weren't so crippling at least.
While I think its absolutely fine to make the odds stacked against me, Springtrap shouldnt be able to teleport from cam 2 to my window in 3 seconds.

Overall, I enjoyed the experience, and this game is SO close to being amazing that its painful to give this game a negative review. But I just love this series too much to just let it be mediocre. The entire time, I felt like a beta tester, and im sure that that isn't what Scott was aiming for.
To be perfectly honest, if this game gets a good patch or two, and most of these cons get fixed, I will certainly change my review.
This game has the potential to be a strong title in the series so long as these glaring issues are dealt with.
Overall, I would rate this game at 6.5/10 until its fixed. (No matter how badly I want to give it 9/10)

Until then, Cheers, and keep up the great work, Scott. Can't wait to see what you come up with next.

reviewText:
3 games in and Scott Cawthon hasn't learnt anything from his previous mistakes. This is a game series that revolves around learning a few key mechanics and just repeating them over and over whilst hoping that the odds are in your favor and the randomized placement of the monsters is fair enough to let you progresss. This time you're working the control room as Freddy's has now been turned into an amusement park attraction.

There's 1 robot that's come to life and the others are mere hallucinations which cause you to have some sort of seizure and ultimately black out. It's a combination of lightning fast reflexes and just blind luck that becomes annoying very quickly. We're still not given a proper options menu or save system and the game is still running in an ugly 4:3 resolution that warps when played full screen.

You have to admire this guy (Scott Cawthon) though for what he's done single handedly. He's created a huge fanbase, mostly Lets Players, but there is rich and compelling lore to uncover and the games have a terrifying atmosphere with lots of frightening jump scares.

I guess I had just hoped that by the third game, it would've been more than just slightly changed gameplay and a new setting. If you're a fan of the older games I guess this one has to be played out of necessity, but people who were on the fence about the previous games aren't going to be swayed.

Full video review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W9U0IiKm0ik

reviewText:
This is really hard to say...


I am possibly one of the biggest fans of this game. I'm massively active and reasonably well known in the fan base, I've actually contacted the creator personally, and I've played and beaten every game in the series. I am a REALLY big fan of the series.

But I'm actually disappointed by this game.

FNAF 1 was something new, unique, and different. It had an atmosphere that chokes you, claustrophobia and some agoraphobia at the SAME TIME, and everything about it was terrifying. I've beat the game, and still it terrifies me.

FNAF 2 was an exciting sequel- it introduced loads of cool mechanics, changed everything round HUGELY, and completely revamped the awesome story. It was brilliant. Not as scary as the first one once you got used to it, but it still scares occasionally. I love both of those games, and completely recommend you get them. If you don't have them, get them.

FNAF 3 is just... not as scary. It doesn't have any of the atmosphere that the two earlier games have, and the horror in it is almost not there. I was terrified to play it the first time- certain things made me crap myself. Things such as Mangle outside my window freaked me out, since I had no idea what was happening. The first time I put my camera down and saw Freddy limping across past my window, I almost cried. I was terrified- what do I do? What's going to happen? Then he jumpscared me and I screamed, blah blah blah. I saw the creepy Chica face, got jumpscared, screamed. Saw Foxy in my room- you see where this is going. But now, almost two weeks after the game came out, I'm used to it. 4 hours in, and I'm getting kinda bored.

There's a LOT to do- to get the good ending, you need to hunt down all the hidden minigames then beat them in the secret way, which will involve playing through the entire 5 nights again. Or, should I say, 4 nights. There is nothing to do on Night 1, at all. No enemies. Unlike the first two games, where Night 1 would throw you in at the deep end with an easy yet still failable night so you are forced to learn all the mechanics- quick! In this one, nothing happens on Night 1. You listen to the new Phone Guy talk to you, then flip bored between the cameras for 3 in game hours.  There is a plot reason- Springtrap, the new animatronic, hadn't been discovered by this point. But still, from a gameplay point of view, it's disappointing.

More about Springtrap- he's your only enemy in this game. There are hallucinations which will show up to jumpscare you occasionally, but Springtrap is the only one who will end your game. Such a shame, then, that he's totally unscary. I can see what Scott Cawthon, creator of the game, was doing with the design... Bonnie, probably the scariest antagonist of the first two games, is represented in a 'zombie' form. This makes sense plot wise, of course- but that would be a spoiler. But the 'zombie' version just isn't frightening. The original animatronics were scary because of their 'uncanny valley' appearance, kid friendly cartoon animals coming for your blood. So when the antagonist is a generic zombie creature, that unique little spark is gone.

Plot-wise, this game is possibly the best so far. The minigame after Night 5 made me absolutely freak out- it was my personal favourite moment in the Five Nights at Freddy's series. It beat the FNAF 1 Night 5 phone call to the absolute best moment. So that's a pro.

But despite this, I really hate to say that this game is unrecommended. I like the game- if it was standalone, I'd be here singing it's praises. But it doesn't live up to the previous games on the horror scale. The atmosphere that I so loved in the previous games is dead and gone. I went into this game at first hoping it would be incredible. It was certainly hyped, and I stayed up all night refreshing all the associated pages, and ended up disappointed.

So when I say this game is unrecommended, I am by no means saying don't buy it. If you have the previous games, get it- for plot reasons, if nothing else. But seeing as this game is a horror, I feel I should judge it as such. The parts of the game that scared me most at first now make me laugh out loud- Freddy limping, for example, is thoroughly hilarious to sing 'Gotta Go Fast' or 'One Way Or Another' to. Unlike the first games, the horror has worn off for me already.

I'm giving it a thumbs up because the developer deserves the money. The game deserves positive reviews, and the series deserves love.

reviewText: I love this. It has a better mechanic than the others, because you have to actually look at the cameras and see where Springtrap is. It has the feel of a fan-game, though. It didn't meet my expectations, which was to be more...dark. It revealed a lot of story on the important part. I probably would want the development to be a month longer, because that's how long the other game took, and they had a good feel to them. Anyways, I totally love this game, and I can't wait for all of the story to be revealed for us hardcore theorists in a likely 4th and maybe even 5th game. If the story isn't revealed by then, you, Scott, can make a spinoff with a lot of minigames. Thank you for reading. Remember to smile, you are the face of Freddy Fazbear's Pizza.

reviewText:
For people who are new to the third installment in the franchise, prepare for a game of ''chess'' where the opponent keeps staying one step ahead of you at all time, and you need to keep putting up strategic moves to keep him out of the room.

And for the people who have played the the first two games, prepare for something that you've already seen in the last games but with a few new tweaks and a fleshed out system to keep you and your stress under control.

As my personal thought on this game, it was slightly better than the second but not as effective as the first.
Either way, i had alot of fun and got closure from beating this game <3

reviewText:
If you like strategic horror games that keep you on the edge of your seat, this game is for you. The eastereggs scott hides makes the game all the better, and the random terrifying images of springtrap that appear before starting a night can be enough to have you abandoning your computer. Basically the reason why half of the people who reviewed this game have less than 20 minutes of playtime.

The gameplay is smooth, and very scary for the first week or two you play it. But eventually you get used to the repetitive and predictable jumpscares, and you can stare at the screen with a straight face while foxy jumps at the screen. This game can cause some great jumpscares, but only when you first buy it. The designs of the restaraunt and animatronics are very well done, and the animations (ex. springtrap walking across the glass window) will have you tensing up.

The game is fun at first, but ends up making you do the same thing over and over, but only harder each time. It is very repetitive, but will keep you in your seat to see what happens next. The minigames to support the storyline are practically the only difference in each level after reaching around night 3.

Now, just because it is repetitive, does not mean it is not entertaining. The new ventallation/audio/camera system makes the game all the more tense. And to see springtrap run behind the camera basically means to brace for a jumpscare.

Graphics: 8.5/10

Horror: 7/10

Entertainment: 8/10

Storyline: 10/10

Overall: 8.5/10

date: I am a teacher and decided to by this game. This game is good to show your students in health class. But before I tell you why
recommended: here is the general story behind the game.\n\nYou play as a man who decided to attach his camera & reboot systems to the wall and the floor
hoursPlayed: so he can... You know... Get some more exercise out of it by turning his chair every time. He must night watch the horror attraction and make sure people don't steal from the building (honestly who is going to steal what from a horror attraction -_-).\n\nYou must make sure those vents are always working
voteText: because they prevent the additional LSD from going through the vents and into your room. If they stop working
helpfulPercent: that is when
votesHelpful: as the phone guy states
votesTotal: "you start seeing some crazy things". This is why it is good for health class
votesFunny: because you can scare your kids and show them what happens when you start hallucinating.\n\nBalloon boy also tends to walk around and make those annoying noises again. As I said in my last review
commentsCount: he graduated from the finest school of engineering and can disable your lights. But he died. So now he can't do any of that stuff (HA HA SUCK IT) and you may keep him away from your office by using audio in the camera system. Scott removed this of course
column16: but the song that would play is "another one bites the dust"
column17: and so he would go to it. Why? I don't know.\n\nNow
column18: you have to keep this "spring trap" thing away from your office. He is lonely and is looking for someone to pull his spring trap
column19: because he wants to die. He can't reach it though. To be a good role model
column20: you must say no and refuse to pull the trap. But if he gets up in your face and forces you to pull it
column21: you are screwed and will feel guilty for the rest of your life. But
column23: you may tell a trusted adult about the situation.\n\nI love this game more than the last one. 10/10 Scott. Oh yeah and also
column24: remember to ALWAYS close your camera on the screen where you see a hallucination. It will go away.\n"

reviewText: Five Nights at Freddy's 3 is the fear-inducing, tear-jerking, heartwarming (possible) finale of the series.\nThe controls are swift, the graphics are realistic, and the story (which I will not spoil) is awesome. Nothing more I can ask for.\n

reviewText:
Five Nights At Freddy's 3 has finally came out and it lives up to the past two games. This game will have you guessing and jumping out of your seat the whole time....

Pros

[+] System Reboots make the game hard and adds a unique experience
[+] Creepy Atomosphere
[+] Has past animatronics in a intreasting way
[+] Has an Extra Menu, where you can put on cheats and look at other cool things
[+] Introduces Springtrap. My favorite in the series

Cons

[-] Can be very hard to get used to
[-] Night 2 is hard for the second night

Gameplay Rating: GREAT
Content Rating: OUTSTANDING
OVERALL RATING: OUTSTANDING (90/100)

reviewText:
This game is probably my favourite out of the three FNAF games, since it wraps up big aspects of the story well, and it really makes you stress from all the games mechanics. Scott has really improved on the games, since now he can manage to make the animatronics actually move infront of your eyes. Scotts thing about 'Only one' really worked out, since the older animatronics are now in hallucination form.

My main issue with the game is that the jumpscares arent very scary, since most of the time you can see them coming. For example, if you see Phantom BB on the cameras, you know you will be jumpscared. They arent that scary in general too. Another issue is that it dosent really explain the mechanics that well to you, I dont know how to get rid of SpringTrap when he is in your office window/ door.

Overall, it is a very good game.

reviewText: An amazing horror experience for anyone who likes being scared...for the first few jumps. True, this game is still scary, as I still jump every now and again at the jumpscares, especially Foxy's (that son of a ♥♥♥♥♥). Anyway, the mechanics are a LOT different from the last two and the camera is the main focus of the game rather than the office for once, and that's a welcome change. This game is also easier than the last two by far, though that isn't a bad thing. If you're looking for a scary experience that lasts, this isn't it. I would recommend this to people that are just starting to get into the FNaF series. Great game overall, it just doesn't have the same impact on me as the other two did.

reviewText: So, what do I think of this game? Overall: pretty good, though the jumpscares got repetitive. Hell, I could probably make a rave of this. It's definitely a good thing that this game brought an end to the series, though the setting could've been, well, improved. Springtrap was a rave jumpscare, and the Phantoms aren't particularly scary if you get jumpscared by them a lot. However, I recommend this one over the older ones, as this one is a bit more forgiving on the first night, getting the player used to the game. My rating: 7.2/10\n\nNOTE: If you're wondering why I have low hours, it's cause I play the mobile version as well.

reviewText:
The 3rd game in the Five nights at Freddy's series, you are, again, a security guard working the night shift, defending yourself with closing vents and directing Springtrap away from you with noises.

Pros:
-Changes the system a little, which can intimidate the player.
-The first night is more of a tutorial night, with Springtrap inactive so you can get used to the controls without threats.

Cons:
-Very easy to beat (I beat it without dying. By the way, it was the first time that I played it)
-Not a very obvious way to get rid of some of the phantom animatronics

Its a good game 9/10

reviewText: SPOILERS AHEAD!!\n\nAMAZING. This game was a very big improvment from the 2nd game. You get to seal vents, play Balloon Boy (STILL SO ANNOYING!!!!!!!!!!) noises, mini-games, and an extra menu, where you can see all of the animatronics (Well, 2 of Springtrap, and none of Phantom Mangle, so that sux), their jumpscares (S. reviewText:
This one, in my opinion, is possibly the most challenging thus far. In fact, it is almost TOO challenging but FNAF has always been more of a stress simulator than a horror simulator.

FNAF 3 is littered with jumpscares that not only scare Christ himself out of you, but also leave you vulnerable. Rebooting needs to be considered and planned out to save time.

This particular game likes to give you confidence that it isn't going to be so hard the first two nights but quickly robs you of that and brings you back to what this game originally was... a stress simulator in the horror genre.

If you follow the story, then this one keeps your head filled with answers as well as questions to counter-balance the mindscrewing the series has always used against its players.

It is just so freaking difficult!

8.5/10

reviewText:
Play the original.
Only play the second one if you're desperate.
Then for a truly horrifying experience, play this one, I'm only on Night 3 and it's already my favourite game of 2015. Scott (The Developer) clearly knew that he'd have to change the core mechanics else it would be too repeatitive, and boy was he right. This game stands out above it's prequels as being even more isolated than the rest. If you haven't already, avoid ANY gameplay. Why? you ask, because I did exactly that and it only made the game even more surprising. Scott has created a remarkable series of horror games, now let's just hope that he doesn't ruin it by milking it.
Even if you think that only ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥" get scared at FNAF play it for the backstory. Most people are just writing fan - fictions but there are some people who very interesting (Game) theories.
As well as the numerous easter eggs hinting at the events that took place."

reviewText:
The 3rd game in the Five nights at Freddy's series, you are, again, a security guard working the night shift, defending yourself with closing vents and directing Springtrap away from you with noises.

Pros:
-Changes the system a little, which can intimidate the player.
-The first night is more of a tutorial night, with Springtrap inactive so you can get used to the controls without threats.

Cons:
-Very easy to beat (I beat it without dying. By the way, it was the first time that I played it)
-Not a very obvious way to get rid of some of the phantom animatronics

Its a good game 9/10

reviewText: This is the third game in the FNAF series. This game is different in a couple ways. Unlike before, there are actually TWO endings, a good and a bad ending. Obviously the good ending requires more work to get. There is a Nightmare mode, and an Extras menu. Now, onto the gameplay. There is one animatronic, he doesn't appear on Night 1, it's just the phone call on that night. Night 2 and beyond, he appears. You have to keep him away from your office at basically almost all times. You can use sounds in the cameras to lure him to a room next to the room he is in. You also have to worry about the audio devices, cameras, and ventilation errors, which then, you have to reset them to have them working again. In my opinion, this was the easiest FNAF game. That was my review on FNAF3, with no actual spoilers in terms of story. If you have the other two games, this is a must buy. 10/10 Great game, great story, much fun.

reviewText: An amazing horror experience for anyone who likes being scared...for the first few jumps. True, this game is still scary, as I still jump every now and again at the jumpscares, especially Foxy's (that son of a ♥♥♥♥♥). Anyway, the mechanics are a LOT different from the last two and the camera is the main focus of the game rather than the office for once, and that's a welcome change. This game is also easier than the last two by far, though that isn't a bad thing. If you're looking for a scary experience that lasts, this isn't it. I would recommend this to people that are just starting to get into the FNaF series. Great game overall, it just doesn't have the same impact on me as the other two did.

reviewText:
Five Nights at Freddy's 3 reminds us that even though changing some features for a game, it doesn't always mean that the game isn't the exact same as the previous one. Don't get me wrong, this is a great game. Its just, the original was so much better than this game, and even though I love this game, the features aren't all that great. The story however, is one of the best parts of this game, more so than the features. The game is noticeably not as scary as the original, but compared to the second game, it is almost as scary. The game still remains as mysterious as the other ones, but with some things revealed more than the past games.

Story:

Just like the other games, the backstory for this game is truly amazing from what we can see. The ending is so much better than the previous games, and provides an amazing experience story wise.

Verdict:

This game definitely is not as good as the original, and falls shorter than the previous sequel to the original. Although this game is scary at first, it does fail to scare you as much as the original game did, and although the game's story is great, the game's features could have been so much better.

Rating:

6.5/10

+ Deep Story
+ Amazing Animations
+ Detailed Atmosphere

- Game isn't as scary as intended.
- Formula is definitely starting to get worse.
- Features aren't all that great.

Buy this if you like Five Nights at Freddy's, if you don't; do not buy this game.

reviewText:
Should you buy Five Nights At Freddy's 3?
If you're a fan of the series,  just do it.  It's more of what you already know to be good, and it ties up the story so far really well.

If you've never played the FNAF series before, I highly recommend you pick up the first Five Nights At Freddy's game, it's super cheap and it's a whole lot of fun. The scares wear off eventually, and you become a little more impervious to what it throws at you. But what the jumpscares (eventually) lack, the backstory and plot certainly play a huge redeeming factor afterwards, too.

reviewText:
Hello everyone, i just wanted to do a review on this game mainly because i've never done a review before on a game but also it's because i love this game!. First off when i loaded the game up the menu music is quite catchy but thats a personal thing xD, what really suprised me in this game is how dark and different it felt to all of the other games. I'm sure all of you know that fnaf1 and fnaf2 had a certain feel to it that made it feel like Five night's at freddys, or i'm just insane one or the other. I also like the green tint scott put into the map to give it a uniqe feel.

Anyway i must talk about the gameplay instead of me rambling about my personal obsessions. The camera mechanic has been VASTLY improved from the second game (because most of you all know fnaf2's camera system was broken) i think scott really put this into mind because i feel as if 75% of this game is the camera, and the fact that scott made it hard to see springtrap in that pixelated camera. These momments where you are trying to find springtrap in a camera but you cant find him are probably one of the scarriest momments of this game. The maintenance panel was a huge success! very creepy especially when the ventilation has failed and your just a sitting duck, and then you hear springtrap crawl into the vents. This is probably the most stressful feeling i've felt in a game in a long time (apart from extreme rage xD). And after you complete the 5 nights you unlock nightmare mode, as the name says.. it's a nightmare xD

Ok now i would like to talk about the scare mechanics and the way the animatronics influence me in my play sessions. First off phantom freddy is a great way to stop me from camping the door at 5 am because if he jumpscares me (more on that later) i will have to reset my ventilation which almost always end me up in death from springtrap. Mangle is a great mechanic i must say! its extremely stressful and annoying when you are trying to look for springtrap on the camera but then you have to reset your audio. And for phantom BB, he is quite easy to avoid if your fast enough to switch cameras or put down your camera all together but if your not paying attention he will give you a proper scare sometimes! And now for the puppet, i saved this one for last because i hate it the most xD. I  will find myself trying to look for springtrap and then all of a sudden the puppet pops out, then you have to wait for lke 5 -7 seconds before he goes away and then you have to reset your ventilation which takes like 5 seconds too. It isnt a bad mechanic at all, i just find it annoying at times. Now for the scares, like all scares in horror games they all get you by suprising you. When you first get the game i litreally almost ♥♥♥♥ myself getting jumpscared by phantom freddy, but over time it gets repeatitive and you nearly always know when they are coming. But the magle jumpscare is the most starteling. It's a very loud screach of a corrupted message or something, very scary sometimes!.
but for all of the other jumpscares they all get repeatitive over time, including springtraps.

Ok now that all of the game mechanics are covered i would like to talk about the story and the lore that scott put into this game. I think scott tried his best on this game to cover most of the big theories that people have been debating about since the first game. I really like the minigames you get everytime you pass a night, because i like playing with purple guy by trying to run away from him xD,. which leads me into the minigames themselfs, you are one of the original animatronics in the five nights at freddys 1 pizzeria and every time you follow this mysteroius purple freddy you get the error message of that you cant enter the room he ran to as soon as you try and run away he runs out as purple man and screams and rips you apart. This can be exremly starteling if you just got the game, but as i alluded to before it gets repeatitive after 1 time. But this mini game where you follow purple freddy to a room and jumps at you and rips you apart last for 4 nights. I won't talk about the fifth night minigame as it contains masive spoilers :p.

Now that im over with the minigames i must talk about the legend of the franchise... PHONE GUY, well to me he is a legend xD but this time theres twist this time. As most of you know this game is set in 2017 phone guy from the original pizzerias is most likely dead so instead we get a new phone guy who scott cawthon the developer himself voices as a hip teenager. when i first loaded up this game i found the phone call hillarious to listen too, scott voicing as a over exited teenager was a nice touch. Though i dont know if he was supposed to be the manager or someone else. The training tapes that the original phone guy recorded get played over the phone as you play the game and i think is a nice touch because it really describes the story alot these phone calls, or at least describes what happend on night 5 and why springtrap has a human inside of him.
My biggest complaint about this game is the good ending and the bad ending, sure getting the good ending is a thing to be proud off but what confuses me the most is how 99 percent of people who play this game their first try will get the bad ending after they finish the game for the first time. In my opinion it doesnt seem worth it to play these secret minigames and glitch out of them to get the good ending as all you get is a 3rd star and a different ending screen. Tough i did do it to get the 3rd star it wasnt that fun. But there is one thing that is fun out of all of that... The minigames! i especially love the chica minigame where you collect cake and give it to children, don't ask me why i like this minigame so much xD, but this is a personal complaint. Overall the good ending is a nice touch as it lets people know that the childrens spirits are free, almost makes me happy to think that those kids that got stuffed into a suit are now free and at peace.

Ok i think i'm done now xD i've covered all that i wanted to cover without releasing spoilers (or at least big ones). If anyone took the time to read the whole thing of my lengthy review then thank you because i'm not the best at english and i might of sounded sloppy at times xD. Overall i rate this game as a 8/10 for being fun/scary and stressful at the same time.

This game is pretty good. Forces you to use your camera system more. But it still has some flaws.

The puppet jump scare is almost instant. Where the rest seem to give you some breathing room to react, with the puppet, you better hope you are flipping through randomly and quickly or else he screws you over big time..

The PC version is pretty good.
The mobile version is trash, soooo broken.. Jump scares are unavoidable 100% and Scott never fixed it.

But out of all 3, this was too damn easy.. didn't even die once until night 5.
I only recommend this IF you are a fan of the other games.

But fnaf 1 and 2 are much better than this.
All in all, good game, but way too easy.

reviewText:
First off, I love that when this was released, I was able to play one night each day (...well, one night with Springtrap, anyway, seeing as the first night, you literally aren't doing anything except learning the system), and on my birthday (March 6), I got to the 6th and final night. Still haven't beaten it, but Scott, it's like you knew and planned accordingly! <3

All joking aside, I honestly can't decide if this one or the first game is my favorite. I love the suspense, I love the story breadcrumbs, I love the minigames (I just about died when I found the Chica one. XD It's so damn cute!), and I especially love the ending. I won't spoil it, but I love how it ties up enough of the big questions to feel satisfying, while leaving just enough ambiguity to keep you wondering.

The game mechanics are a LOT better. One thing about the first two games is the cameras, after a few nights, tend to fall into disuse (the first game can be beaten by just quick checks on Freddy and Foxy, and in the second, you have so much going on that really, the only time the cameras are bothered with is for the music box). This one practically keeps you at the cameras, allowing you to take in more details (and hints to the minigames) and explore the area. I also love the two-map system, and the improvement on the second game's vents with the ability to shut them to keep Springtrap out of the office. I also love the phantoms. Sure, I curse and flip off the screen about every time Balloon Boy comes up, but I love that it gives you a quick panic without actually killing you, kind of like seeing Bonnie or Chica at your door in the first game.

I also like that the third game actually takes a bit of skill to play rather than chance. The first game is notorious for the 5am Roulette
date:
where it's up to chance if Freddy plays his full song before killing you or not (along with with whether or not Bonnie and Chica BOTH decide to camp at the doors to waste your power, and for how long they do it), and in the second, with how many animatronics there are gunning for you, winning really CAN depend on the random number generator. For example, there was a later night (3 or 4) where I had the old Bonnie, Freddy, and Chica in my office one after the other with the music box winding down. Because there was literally someone there EVERY DAMN TIME I put down the monitor after winding the box the minimum time I needed to do something else, I didn't have a chance to flick the flashlight to keep Foxy away (guess who killed me that round. XP). But then there was another round of Night 4 where practically no one came, Foxy stayed away, I had plenty of time to keep the box wound, and I had old Bonnie in my office maybe twice the whole night. It was almost like the game was TRYING to be nice and get me onto Night 5 already. XP

This one, however, you have almost complete control of the elements. Phantoms can be avoided by taking quick breaks from the cameras or changing camera views. There's a bit of consistency on when your systems break, so you can account for them and plan accordingly. You can control where Springtrap goes, and you can control how you keep him away from you (sounds and blocking the vents). There's still some chance involved (like the Phantoms, and Springtrap taking advantage of the time it takes you to reboot your system), but overall, living or dying really DOES depend on you, and not how generous the bots feel that night. XP

Overall, I think this is the perfect ending to a great series. It has an excellent conclusion, lots of fun stuff to find, great game play, and even things to unlock. Another game is not necessary; this one beautifully came full circle. I would love for it to end on a high note.

reviewText: Reviewing all of Scott's games again, this one was my favorite. It always gave me chills, for it gave off a fallout or bomb shelter vibe to me. It destroys the mechanics of the last two games almost entirely, and is nothing like the fourth. Also, Springtrap was, for sure, an interesting character to bring to the family. Being more decayed than the withered copies, but not as much as the Nightmares, he was the scariest one around at the time of the release. That is, of course, besides the Phantoms. I'd recommend this game to anyone who'd like burnt and withered animatronics jumpscaring the life out of them. Scott did a good job.

reviewText: Scott Cawthon manages to make the experience unique yet again, it's rather surprising given the speed and quality of the games he's put out. Although the jumpscares have definitely run their course (I honestly stopped being scared of FNAF the after the first 5 days of me huddling in a corner) and have moved onto the second part of the game. The amazing Dark Souls-esque story that encompasses the game. You'll spend your time finding the secret easter egg games and uncovering the dark and interesting story of the resturaunt, or more accurately, reading fan theories because the game is still really stressful to play (oh my god, everything is broken, spring trap is staring at me, and foxy is in the office!)

reviewText: Five Nights at Freddy's 3 is the 3rd, and most likely final, game in the FNaF series. The game looks great, the backstory behind the Purple guy was unexpected, and the Phantom designs were amazing. My only complaint is that the scream isn't that scary to me. For me, Nightmare mode was kinda difficult, because Springtrap was REALLY fast, even when he goes through the vents. But overall, this is a great game and I would recommend it

reviewText: you wanna know why this game is better than the last 2? In the first two games the only time you saw animatronics move were when they jumpscared you. but here, while checking your camera sometimes out of the corner of your eye you wil see that yellow ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ run past your hall window, or worse, RIGHT F-CKING PAST YOU. And then there's phantom freddy who slowly trudges past the window, and if you pay too much attention to him you'll be greated with a gigantic jumpscare. Foxy comes out of nowhere and jumps you with no warning whatsoever. BB graduates from annoying to terrifying. If you catch a glimpse of Phantom chica, it's Jumpscare O' Clock. if you see mangle for even a second it dashes down to your window and makes a screetching sound, attracting Springtrap to your location.  And you know what? Scott Cawthon is a GIGANTIC troll. You know those ungodly sounds BB spouts out all the time in the second game that makes you want to have your ear drums surgically removed?\n\nWell guess what? That is your ONLY LINE OF DEFENSE AGAINST SPRINGTRAP. GG Scott...

reviewText:
Three games. For three damn games I sat, breath withheld, eyelids glues open, hands griped firmly on the mouse, with only one goal. It was simple; don't let them in. Or so I thought. Who knew how hell-bent these animatronics were on stuffing me into the innards of a cute and cuddly stuffed suit? Oh yeah. That was terrifying. Many failures were had. Many ragequits too.

But you know something? I had a lot of fun. I'm not entirely sure why, but I did. Maybe it was the depth of the story combined with how the creator chose to tell it -- with subtle hints and hidden explanations? Or maybe it's because this game nearly sent me into cardiac arrest once or twice, something no horror game has ever done for me. I don't know.

Whatever it is, it worked. It was a simple game, with simple and effective design, and it worked.

reviewText:
I have to give Five Nights at Freddy's creator, Scott Cawthon, some damn well deserved credit, for restoring my interest in horror games, also, thanks for that Scott.

Five Nights at Freddy's 3 is the third in the series, providing a different and yet just as creepy setting for the new location, this time, you work in a amusement park ride, both playing a character and also being the camera man, the game is vastly different than both of it's prequels, with only one animatronic to care for, it should be simple...right?

You have two actual interfaces you can pull up, the system interface, which I will get to later, and the camera interface.

The camera interface allows you to look through the cameras, which are placed around the building, giving you a (not-so) clear view of the place, there are new...gimmicks (not in a bad way) this time.

You have a button to toggle between vent cameras and the main cameras, some of the vents lead straight to your office so by double clicking a vent camera, you can seal that vent, preventing Springtrap from going through it.

You also have another button that allows you to play a sound that attracts him, playing the sound in a room near him will lure him there, you shouldn't play it if he is far away from the room though, he won't be able to hear it.

Now, the system interface is the new thing that handicaps you and prevents the game from being too easy, there are three systems: Ventilation, Camera and Audio.

Ventilation allows you to lock the vents and also keeps the air going through the place, fixing this system is basically nescesarry if it happens, letting it stay broken stops the air from going through, making your guy have panic attacks and hyperventilate which hinders your vision and makes you prone to getting killed by Springtrap and also stops you from sealing the vents, which are spread all around the building and link directly into your office.

Audio allows you to play the sounds, if it breaks, you won't be able to play them, and if you had played them before, it will regenerate much slower while it's broken.

Camera lets you- oh c'mon if you don't know what it does, you shouldn't even be playing this, if it breaks, you won't be able to see anything through the cameras.

These systems can and WILL break through your playthrough, fixing them is critical to your success.

Also, occasionally while looking through the cameras there will be some...surprises that may break your systems at will, pray to RNG before you play this game, because I'm pretty sure that if you don't, you won't be ready.

But then again, you were never ready...never have...never will be ready...you will never, EVER be ready for Freddy...

Game made me make a meme sound dramatic, 8.5/10.

Also, my problems with the game are right at the end, RNG is a ♥♥♥♥ing cheap son of a ♥♥♥♥♥ and Springtrap is also kind of dumb.

reviewText:
This game is not as good as I thought it would so I'm gonna aline the cons and the pros throughout the whole series.

1. The series, not only the game but the series was rushed way too much. Every 3-2 months he released a new game of Five Night's at Freddy's, which made it really rushed and not great. If it was not rushed and took at least 6 months for every game, this series would be amazing! Graphics & Design - 6/10

2. The storyline is great I must say that. This game evolves around 30 years into the future where you are running the nightshift of Fazbear's Fright! They gathered the animontronics from the older places and brought them here for the attraction just to make it seem better. I loved the story through-out the games so I got to make this a pro. Storyline - 10/10

3. The sound was great in this game but it was rushed like the first thing I stated. He used the same jumpscare voice for everyone in the games 1 and 3! Here I'll explain how, In the first game he used the normal jumpscare noise and slowed it down to make golden freddys. In the third he just reversed it and just said, 10/10 perfect" and put it for everysingle animontronic. (Seriously?) The game should have each animontronic a different jumpscare noise it just kills the fun and mystery through the game. Sound - 7/10

4. The jumpscares were great and all but I think they need some work. The spring trap jumpscare was just disapointing :( He just made springtraps jumpscare him walking up to you
date: not even scary at all. The only real scary jumpscare is Balloon Boy which is the Chica jumpscare from FNAF 2. The jumpscares are scary and all but just need some work. Jumpscares - 4/10\n\n5. The gameplay I gotta admit is not that bad
recommended: better than I though atleast BUT
hoursPlayed: as the game was too easy in the last ones he had to make it more complicated with no light and instead you have windows control panel and half to fix the audio errors
voteText:
you ventilation (lmao makes sense?) and the cameras. Not only that but you have to make the balloon boy laugh if where ever you want the spring trap to go. But then there are the Mini-Games to get the good ending which are pretty fun and complicatied. Sooooooo... Gameplay - 8/10

Overall Stats!
--------------
Graphics & Design - 12/20
Story Line - 20/20
Sound - 14/20
Jumpscares - 8/20
Gameplay - 16/20
Total = 70/100 C- This game isn't bad It just could of had more work put into it."

reviewText:
Step one: Look for game in Steam store
Step two: Look at price and beg friends to buy it.
Step three: Have an awesome friend that buys it for you
Step four: Install
Step Five: Run
Step Six: See BB jumpscare and repeat step 5v
Step seven: Learn you can't pause using esc. and that it just closes the game
Step Eight: Reboot Game.
Step Nine: Beat game and gloat to friends
Step Ten: Loose all friends due to being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and remember shortly afterward that it's JUST A F*CKING GAME AND THAT IT ISN'T THAT SCARY!
Step Eleven: Play Again
Step Twelve: Repeat Steps Nine-Eleven until you get bored, also throw in a few Step sixes.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The Game is a very good game, well thought out and good graphics for a 3D game made in less than 4 months. But with quickness, comes glitches and Exploits, like holding up reboot screen for the whole time. *Cough Cough* Totally not a real glitch *Cough Cough* No but in all seriousness, it's a good short horror game with a story that is un-able to be followed.

And always remember, it's a game, try to have fun!

reviewText:
Oh my god, just what a game Scott has made, just wow you need to buy this game or find a friend that already has this game.

The atmosphere in this game is just outstanding! You actually feel like your being hunted by something in real life!

Now let's get started with the threats, there is 1 pyshical animatronic in this game, and 6 other ones from the previous games. The new animatronic in this game is called Spring Trap. He's just the sneakiest of all the animatronics and will hide in the most difficult spots of your camera. You've gotta be checking those cameras alot or you'll be in a lot of trouble. Including the vents, you must seal off the area where Spring Trap is. This animatronics LOVES to play hide and seek with you. He can run past your camera and you might not even see him. He blends in with the walls and darkness easily, so you'll need to concentrate on the walls and darkness. I won't spoil the names of the other animatronics so you can get the best of spooks.

Next, the defense is key in surviving all 5 nights (6 if you feel like playing it) you'll need to play audio throughout the map in order to lure Spring Trap away from you and keep you alive. Like I said earlier, if it's need close a vent area and keep him from entering the left, front and right (which leads straight into your office)

Overall, this game kicks ♥♥♥ than the 2nd one. This one changes your play style and makes you need to check every single camera in the building. This story line for the game is excellent, i'll reccomend this to anyone who feels like getting it. However, when I first saw this game, I felt like it was boring and not buying it because it felt way old in the past, even though it's 30 years later after fnaf 1 took place.

My Rating for this game is: 9/10 - Good Job Scott :)

reviewText:
The fanbase may be annoying as ♥♥♥♥♥. The games themselfes are ok. I liked the previous ones better than this one and the fourth one, but anyway. Let's start the review.

The Pros:

The Art/Graphics: I think that Scott really took his time to make this game, in my opinion. I like both the 3d in-game style and the 2d Atari style.

The Sound: In this game, you will probably spend most of your time listening to different sounds. For example, when Springtrap crawls in the vents.

The Story: The story in this game is still pretty meh, but I like it. Thirty years after Freddy Fazbear's Pizza closed it's doors
date: the events that took place there have become nothing more than a rumor and a childhood memory
recommended: but the owners of "Fazbear's Fright: The Horror Attraction" are determined to revive the legend and make the experience as authentic as possible". You
voteText: work at this "Horror Attraction" and have to

Final Score: 4/10
Play this if you really like FNaF
